title: On the Design of Diffusion-based Neural Speech Codecs
author: Pietro Foti (Fraunhofer IIS Erlangen), Andreas Brendel (Fraunhofer IIS Erlangen)
relevance_why: The paper explores diffusion-based neural speech codecs, aligning closely with Haohe Liu's work on neural audio and speech processing, particularly in terms of innovative audio generation methodologies.
background: Investigating new neural speech codec designs that utilize diffusion models to enhance audio quality and coding efficiency for speech signals.
contribution: This paper introduces a systematic approach to designing diffusion-based neural speech codecs, proposing a comprehensive categorization for different model configurations and evaluating their performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous neural speech codecs predominantly utilized Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), which faced issues like mode collapse.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work explores diffusion models as an alternative, providing a structured framework for investigating various conditioning and output domains, improving generation quality and training stability.

key_innovation: The categorization framework for diffusion-based codecs enables a clearer understanding of design choices and potential impacts on speech generation quality.
real_world_impact: This research may enhance the quality of speech codecs used in low-bitrate scenarios, leading to better audio communication technologies in mobile and internet applications.

new_terms.Neural Speech Codecs: **Neural Speech Codecs (NSCs)** are advanced audio compression systems that leverage neural networks to achieve efficient speech signal encoding and decoding.
new_terms.Diffusion Models: **Diffusion Models (DMs)** are a class of generative models that iteratively convert noise into data samples, effectively allowing for high-quality audio generation through a learned process of noise reduction.
